channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: [Virtual Event] Shields Up: Key Technologies Reshaping Cybersecurity Defenses
Warlock Gang Breaches SmarterTools Via SmarterMail Bugs
item.description: The ransomware group breached SmarterTools through a vulnerability in the company's own SmarterMail product.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: TeamPCP Turns Cloud Infrastructure into Crime Bots
item.description: The threat actor has been compromising cloud environments at scale with automated worm-like attacks on exposed services and interfaces.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: 'Reynolds' Bundles BYOVD With Ransomware Payload
item.description: Researchers discovered a newly disclosed vulnerable driver embedded in Reynolds' ransomware, illustrating the increasing popularity of the defense-evasion technique.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: 23andMe Data Breach Settlement Deadline Is Near: Here’s How Much You Could Get
item.description: <p>23andMe customers affected by a data breach may be eligible for cash or monitoring services. Here’s how to file a claim before the deadline.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-23andme-data-breach-settlement-deadline/">23andMe Data Breach Settlement Deadline Is Near: Here’s How Much You Could Get</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Spotlight On: Futurex, a New Principal Participating Organization
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: New Zero-Click Flaw in Claude Desktop Extensions, Anthropic Declines Fix
item.description: Security researchers from LayerX identified a new flaw in 50 Claude Desktop Extensions that could lead to unauthorized remote code execution

item.title: China-Linked UNC3886 Targets Singapore Telecom Sector in Cyber Espionage Campaign
item.description: The Cyber Security Agency (CSA) of Singapore on Monday revealed that the China-nexus cyber espionage group known as UNC3886 targeted its telecommunications sector. "UNC3886 had launched a deliberate, targeted, and well-planned campaign against Singapore's telecommunications sector," CSA said. "All four of Singapore's major telecommunications operators ('telcos') – M1, SIMBA Telecom, Singtel, and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Two Connecticut Men Charged In Alleged $3m Gambling Fraud Scheme
item.description: Two Connecticut men face federal charges for a $3m scheme targeting online gambling platforms

item.title: VoidLink Malware Exhibits Multi-Cloud Capabilities and AI Code
item.description: VoidLink, a Linux-based C2 framework, facilitates credential theft, data exfiltration across clouds

item.title: SolarWinds Web Help Desk Exploited for RCE in Multi-Stage Attacks on Exposed Servers
item.description: Microsoft has revealed that it observed a multi‑stage intrusion that involved the threat actors exploiting internet‑exposed SolarWinds Web Help Desk (WHD) instances to obtain initial access and move laterally across the organization's network to other high-value assets. That said, the Microsoft Defender Security Research Team said it's not clear whether the activity weaponized recently
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Flickr’s 35M Users Affected by Third-Party Data Exposure
item.description: <p>Flickr disclosed a data exposure tied to a third-party email provider, highlighting how external service vulnerabilities can put millions of users at risk.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-flickr-third-party-email-data-exposure/">Flickr’s 35M Users Affected by Third-Party Data Exposure</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: AI Skill Malware, 31Tbps DDoS, Notepad++ Hack, LLM Backdoors and More
item.description: Cyber threats are no longer coming from just malware or exploits. They’re showing up inside the tools, platforms, and ecosystems organizations use every day. As companies connect AI, cloud apps, developer tools, and communication systems, attackers are following those same paths. A clear pattern this week: attackers are abusing trust. Trusted updates, trusted marketplaces, trusted apps, even
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: LLMs are Getting a Lot Better and Faster at Finding and Exploiting Zero-Days
item.description: <p>This is <a href="https://red.anthropic.com/2026/zero-days/">amazing</a>:</p> <blockquote><p>Opus 4.6 is notably better at finding high-severity vulnerabilities than previous models and a sign of how quickly things are moving. Security teams have been automating vulnerability discovery for years, investing heavily in fuzzing infrastructure and custom harnesses to find bugs at scale. But what stood out in early testing is how quickly Opus 4.6 found vulnerabilities out of the box without task-specific tooling, custom scaffolding, or specialized prompting. Even more interesting is how it found them. Fuzzers work by throwing massive amounts of random inputs at code to see what breaks. Opus 4.6 reads and reasons about code the way a human researcher would­&#8212;looking at past fixes to find similar bugs that weren&#8217;t addressed, spotting patterns that tend to cause problems, or understanding a piece of logic well enough to know exactly what input would break it. When we pointed Opus 4.6 at some of the most well-tested codebases (projects that have had fuzzers running against them for years, ...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: How Top CISOs Solve Burnout and Speed up MTTR without Extra Hiring
item.description: Why do SOC teams keep burning out and missing SLAs even after spending big on security tools? Routine triage piles up, senior specialists get dragged into basic validation, and MTTR climbs, while stealthy threats still find room to slip through. Top CISOs have realized the solution isn’t hiring more people or stacking yet another tool onto the workflow, but giving their teams faster, clearer
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: BridgePay Confirms Ransomware Attack, No Card Data Compromised
item.description: The services of Florida-based payments platform BridgePay are offline due to a ransomware attack

item.title: Bloody Wolf Targets Uzbekistan, Russia Using NetSupport RAT in Spear-Phishing Campaign
item.description: The threat actor known as Bloody Wolf has been linked to a campaign targeting Uzbekistan and Russia to infect systems with a remote access trojan known as NetSupport RAT. Cybersecurity vendor Kaspersky is tracking the activity under the moniker Stan Ghouls. The threat actor is known to be active since at least 2023, orchestrating spear-phishing attacks against manufacturing, finance, and IT
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Social Media Platforms Earn Billions from Scam Ads
item.description: Revolut claims social media sites make £3.8bn annually from scam ads targeting European users

item.title: Researchers Find 40,000+ Exposed OpenClaw Instances
item.description: SecurityScorecard has identified over 40,000 OpenClaw deployments exposed to potential attack

item.title: US Agencies Told to Scrap End of Support Edge Devices
item.description: CISA has issued a new directive requiring federal agencies to decommission all end of support edge devices within 12 months to reduce ongoing exploitation risks

item.title: TeamPCP Worm Exploits Cloud Infrastructure to Build Criminal Infrastructure
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have called attention to a "massive campaign" that has systematically targeted cloud native environments to set up malicious infrastructure for follow-on exploitation. The activity, observed around December 25, 2025, and described as "worm-driven," leveraged exposed Docker APIs, Kubernetes clusters, Ray dashboards, and Redis servers, along with the recently disclosed
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: BeyondTrust Fixes Critical Pre-Auth RCE Vulnerability in Remote Support and PRA
item.description: BeyondTrust has released updates to address a critical security flaw impacting Remote Support (RS) and Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products that, if successfully exploited, could result in remote code execution. "BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and certain older versions of Privileged Remote Access (PRA) contain a critical pre-authentication remote code execution vulnerability," the company
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: OpenClaw Integrates VirusTotal Scanning to Detect Malicious ClawHub Skills
item.description: OpenClaw (formerly Moltbot and Clawdbot) has announced that it's partnering with Google-owned VirusTotal to scan skills that are being uploaded to ClawHub, its skill marketplace, as part of broader efforts to bolster the security of the agentic ecosystem. "All skills published to ClawHub are now scanned using VirusTotal's threat intelligence, including their new Code Insight capability,"
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: German Agencies Warn of Signal Phishing Targeting Politicians, Military, Journalists
item.description: Germany's Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution (aka Bundesamt für Verfassungsschutz or BfV) and Federal Office for Information Security (BSI) have issued a joint advisory warning of a malicious cyber campaign undertaken by a likely state-sponsored threat actor that involves carrying out phishing attacks over the Signal messaging app. "The focus is on high-ranking targets in
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Friday Squid Blogging: Squid Fishing Tips
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Asian Cyber Espionage Campaign Breached 37 Countries
item.description: <p>Palo Alto Networks says an Asian cyber espionage campaign breached 70 organizations in 37 countries, targeting government agencies and critical infrastructure.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-asian-cyber-espionage-campaign-breached-37-countries/">Asian Cyber Espionage Campaign Breached 37 Countries</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Kezia Jungco

item.title: I Am in the Epstein Files
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Chinese-Made Malware Kit Targets Chinese-Based Routers and Edge Devices
item.description: DKnife is a Chinese made malware framework that targets Chinese-based users

item.title: 'Encrypt It Already' Campaign Pushes Big Tech to Prioritize E2E Encryption
item.description: The Electronic Frontier Foundation is urging major technology companies to follow through on their promises to implement end-to-end encryption (E2E) by default across their services, as privacy concerns mount amid increased AI use.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: Shai-hulud: The Hidden Costs of Supply Chain Attacks
item.description: Recent supply chain attacks involving self-propagating worms have spread far, but the damage and long-term impact is hard to quantify.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Substack Confirms Data Breach, "Limited User Data" Compromised
item.description: Substack did not specify the number of users affected by the data breach

item.title: OpenClaw's Gregarious Insecurities Make Safe Usage Difficult
item.description: Malicious &quot;skills&quot; and persnickety configuration settings are just some of the issues that security researchers have found when installing — and removing — the OpenClaw AI assistant.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Why Rising Cybersecurity Spend Still Isn’t Convincing Boards on ROI in APAC
item.description: <p>Cybersecurity budgets are rising across APAC, but CIOs and CISOs still face board scrutiny. Here’s why cybersecurity ROI remains hard to prove.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/cybersecurity-roi-in-apac/">Why Rising Cybersecurity Spend Still Isn’t Convincing Boards on ROI in APAC</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Sasha Menon

item.title: China-Linked DKnife AitM Framework Targets Routers for Traffic Hijacking, Malware Delivery
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have taken the wraps off a gateway-monitoring and adversary-in-the-middle (AitM) framework dubbed DKnife that's operated by China-nexus threat actors since at least 2019. The framework comprises seven Linux-based implants that are designed to perform deep packet inspection, manipulate traffic, and deliver malware via routers and edge devices. Its primary targets seem to
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISA Orders Removal of Unsupported Edge Devices to Reduce Federal Network Risk
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has ordered Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies to strengthen asset lifecycle management for edge network devices and remove those that no longer receive security updates from original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) over the next 12 to 18 months. The agency said the move is to drive down technical debt and minimize
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Asian State-Backed Group TGR-STA-1030 Breaches 70 Government, Infrastructure Entities
item.description: A previously undocumented cyber espionage group operating from Asia broke into the networks of at least 70 government and critical infrastructure organizations across 37 countries over the past year, according to new findings from Palo Alto Networks Unit 42. In addition, the hacking crew has been observed conducting active reconnaissance against government infrastructure associated with 155
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: iPhone Lockdown Mode Protects Washington Post Reporter
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: How Samsung Knox Helps Stop Your Network Security Breach
item.description: As you know, enterprise network security has undergone significant evolution over the past decade. Firewalls have become more intelligent, threat detection methods have advanced, and access controls are now more detailed. However (and it&rsquo;s a big &ldquo;however&rdquo;), the increasing use of mobile devices in business operations necessitates network security measures that are specifically
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Compromised dYdX npm and PyPI Packages Deliver Wallet Stealers and RAT Malware

item.title: New Cyber Startup Programme to Debut at Infosecurity Europe 2026
item.description: Infosecurity Europe 2026 will debut a new Cyber Startup Programme, featuring a dedicated show-floor zone for early-stage cybersecurity companies to showcase innovations, connect with investors and highlight emerging technologies

item.title: Claude Opus 4.6 Finds 500+ High-Severity Flaws Across Major Open-Source Libraries
item.description: Artificial intelligence (AI) company Anthropic revealed that its latest large language model (LLM), Claude Opus 4.6, has found more than 500 previously unknown high-severity security flaws in open-source libraries, including Ghostscript, OpenSC, and CGIF. Claude Opus 4.6, which was launched Thursday, comes with improved coding skills, including code review and debugging capabilities, along with
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: EnCase Driver Weaponized as EDR Killers Persist
item.description: The forensic tool's driver was signed with a digital certificate that expired years ago, but major security gaps allowed Windows to load it.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Agentic AI Site 'Moltbook' Is Riddled With Security Risks
item.description: Someone used AI to build an entire Web platform, which then did something predictable and preventable: It exposed all its data through a publicly accessible API.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Data Tool to Triage Exploited Vulnerabilities Can Make KEV More Useful
item.description: A disconnect exists between an organization's cybersecurity needs and lists like CISA's KEV Catalog. KEV Collider combines data from multiple open source vulnerability frameworks to help security teams quickly assess which are important, based on their priorities.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Chrome Vulnerabilities Allow Code Execution, Browser Crashes
item.description: <p>Google released a Chrome security update fixing two high-severity flaws that could enable code execution or crashes via malicious websites.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-google-chrome-security-update-february-2026/">Chrome Vulnerabilities Allow Code Execution, Browser Crashes</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: Microsoft Overhauls Security Leadership as AI Expands Enterprise Attack Surface
item.description: <p>Microsoft brings back Hayete Gallot to lead Security while Charlie Bell moves to an engineering quality mandate, both reporting to CEO Satya Nadella.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-gallot-security-bell-engineering-quality/">Microsoft Overhauls Security Leadership as AI Expands Enterprise Attack Surface</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Liz Ticong

item.title: AISURU/Kimwolf Botnet Launches Record-Setting 31.4 Tbps DDoS Attack
item.description: The distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) botnet known as AISURU/Kimwolf has been attributed to a record-setting attack that peaked at 31.4 Terabits per second (Tbps) and lasted only 35 seconds. Cloudflare, which automatically detected and mitigated the activity, said it's part of a growing number of hyper-volumetric HTTP DDoS attacks mounted by the botnet in the fourth quarter of 2025. The
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Malicious Commands in GitHub Codespaces Enable RCE
item.description: Flaws in GitHub Codespaces allow RCE via crafted repositories or pull requests

item.title: Cyber Success Trifecta: Education, Certifications &amp; Experience
item.description: Col. Georgeo Xavier Pulikkathara, CISO at iMerit, discusses the importance of fundamentals, continuous learning, and human ingenuity in the face of AI-driven cybersecurity evolution.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Beek

item.title: Smartphones Now Involved in Nearly Every Police Investigation
item.description: Cellebrite data confirms digital evidence is now central to almost all cases

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: Codespaces RCE, AsyncRAT C2, BYOVD Abuse, AI Cloud Intrusions & 15+ Stories
item.description: This week didn’t produce one big headline. It produced many small signals — the kind that quietly shape what attacks will look like next. Researchers tracked intrusions that start in ordinary places: developer workflows, remote tools, cloud access, identity paths, and even routine user actions. Nothing looked dramatic on the surface. That’s the point. Entry is becoming less visible while impact
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Backdoor in Notepad++
item.description: <p>Hackers associated with the Chinese government used a <a href="https://arstechnica.com/security/2026/02/notepad-updater-was-compromised-for-6-months-in-supply-chain-attack/">Trojaned version</a> of Notepad++ to deliver malware to selected users.</p> <blockquote><p>Notepad++ said that officials with the unnamed provider hosting the update infrastructure consulted with incident responders and found that it remained compromised until September 2. Even then, the attackers maintained credentials to the internal services until December 2, a capability that allowed them to continue redirecting selected update traffic to malicious servers. The threat actor &#8220;specifically targeted Notepad++ domain with the goal of exploiting insufficient update verification controls that existed in older versions of Notepad++.&#8221; Event logs indicate that the hackers tried to re-exploit one of the weaknesses after it was fixed but that the attempt failed...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: New Hacking Campaign Exploits Microsoft Windows WinRAR Vulnerability
item.description: Researchers at Check Point link ‘Amarath-Dragon’ attacks to prolific Chinese cyber-espionage operation

item.title: The Buyer’s Guide to AI Usage Control
item.description: Today’s “AI everywhere” reality is woven into everyday workflows across the enterprise, embedded in SaaS platforms, browsers, copilots, extensions, and a rapidly expanding universe of shadow tools that appear faster than security teams can track. Yet most organizations still rely on legacy controls that operate far away from where AI interactions actually occur. The result is a widening
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Varonis Acquires AllTrue to Strengthen AI Security Capabilities
item.description: <p>The deal underscores a broader industry shift as security vendors race to address the risks introduced by LLMs, copilots, and autonomous AI agents.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-varonis-buys-alltrue/">Varonis Acquires AllTrue to Strengthen AI Security Capabilities</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: European Officials Warn of Russian Satellites Intercepting Communications
item.description: <p>Russian Luch “inspector” satellites are suspected of shadowing European GEO spacecraft, raising fears of interception, jamming, and orbital risk.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-europe-warning-russian-satellites/">European Officials Warn of Russian Satellites Intercepting Communications</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Madeline Clarke

item.title: Infy Hackers Resume Operations with New C2 Servers After Iran Internet Blackout Ends
item.description: The elusive Iranian threat group known as Infy (aka Prince of Persia) has evolved its tactics as part of efforts to hide its tracks, even as it readied new command-and-control (C2) infrastructure coinciding with the end of the widespread internet blackout the regime imposed at the start of January 2026. "The threat actor stopped maintaining its C2 servers on January 8 for the first time since we
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI-Enabled Voice and Virtual Meeting Fraud Surges 1000%+
item.description: Pindrop warns of 1210% increase in AI-powered fraud last year

item.title: Protests Don't Impede Iranian Spying on Expats, Syrians, Israelis
item.description: Iranian threat actors have been stealing credentials from people of interest across the Middle East, using spear-phishing and social engineering.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Critical n8n Flaw CVE-2026-25049 Enables System Command Execution via Malicious Workflows
item.description: A new, critical security vulnerability has been disclosed in the n8n workflow automation platform that, if successfully exploited, could result in the execution of arbitrary system commands. The flaw, tracked as CVE-2026-25049 (CVSS score: 9.4), is the result of inadequate sanitization that bypasses safeguards put in place to address CVE-2025-68613 (CVSS score: 9.9), another critical defect that
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Malicious NGINX Configurations Enable Large-Scale Web Traffic Hijacking Campaign
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of an active web traffic hijacking campaign that has targeted NGINX installations and management panels like Baota (BT) in an attempt to route it through the attacker's infrastructure. Datadog Security Labs said it observed threat actors associated with the recent React2Shell (CVE-2025-55182, CVSS score: 10.0) exploitation using malicious NGINX
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Ransomware Gang Goes Full 'Godfather' With Cartel
item.description: DragonForce is taking cues from organized crime, emphasizing cooperation and coordination among ransomware gangs.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: CISA Makes Unpublicized Ransomware Updates to KEV Catalog
item.description: A third of the &quot;flipped&quot; CVEs affected network edge devices, leading one researcher to conclude, &quot;Ransomware operators are building playbooks around your perimeter.&quot;
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Attackers Use Windows Screensavers to Drop Malware, RMM Tools
item.description: By tapping the unusual .scr file type, attackers leverage &quot;executables that don't always receive executable-level controls,&quot; one researcher noted.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Microsoft Develops Scanner to Detect Backdoors in Open-Weight Large Language Models
item.description: Microsoft on Wednesday said it built a lightweight scanner that it said can detect backdoors in open-weight large language models (LLMs) and improve the overall trust in artificial intelligence (AI) systems. The tech giant's AI Security team said the scanner leverages three observable signals that can be used to reliably flag the presence of backdoors while maintaining a low false positive
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: DEAD#VAX Malware Campaign Deploys AsyncRAT via IPFS-Hosted VHD Phishing Files
item.description: Threat hunters have disclosed details of a new, stealthy malware campaign dubbed DEAD#VAX that employs a mix of "disciplined tradecraft and clever abuse of legitimate system features" to bypass traditional detection mechanisms and deploy a remote access trojan (RAT) known as AsyncRAT. "The attack leverages IPFS-hosted VHD files, extreme script obfuscation, runtime decryption, and in-memory
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Global SystemBC Botnet Found Active Across 10,000 Infected Systems
item.description: SystemBC malware linked to 10,000 infected IPs, posing risks to sensitive government infrastructure

item.title: New Technical Markers Reveal Expanding ShadowSyndicate Cybercriminal Infrastructure
item.description: ShadowSyndicate cluster expands with new SSH fingerprints connecting servers to other ransomware ops

item.title: China-Linked Amaranth-Dragon Exploits WinRAR Flaw in Espionage Campaigns
item.description: Threat actors affiliated with China have been attributed to a fresh set of cyber espionage campaigns targeting government and law enforcement agencies across Southeast Asia throughout 2025. Check Point Research is tracking the previously undocumented activity cluster under the moniker Amaranth-Dragon, which it said shares links to the APT 41 ecosystem. Targeted countries include Cambodia,
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI Drives Doubling of Phishing Attacks in a Year
item.description: Cofense claims AI is making phishing emails more personalized and sophisticated

item.title: Extra Extra! Announcing DR Global Latin America
item.description: Dark Reading has something new hitting the newsstand: a content section purpose-built for Latin American readers, featuring news, analysis, features, and multimedia.
item.dc:creator: Tara Seals

item.title: Big Breach or Smooth Sailing? Mexican Gov't Faces Leak Allegations
item.description: A hacktivist group claims a 2.3-terabyte data breach exposes the information of 36 million Mexicans, but no sensitive accounts are at risk, says government.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Two Critical Flaws in n8n AI Workflow Automation Platform Allow Complete Takeover
item.description: Pillar Security discovered two new critical vulnerabilities in n8n that could lead to supply chain compromise, credential harvesting and complete takeover attacks

item.title: US Declassifies Information on JUMPSEAT Spy Satellites
item.description: <p>The US National Reconnaissance Office has declassified <a href="https://arstechnica.com/space/2026/01/us-spy-satellite-agency-declassifies-high-flying-cold-war-listening-post/">information</a> about a fleet of spy satellites operating between 1971 and 2006.</p> <p>I&#8217;m actually impressed to see a declassification only two decades after decommission.</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Orchid Security Introduces Continuous Identity Observability for Enterprise Applications
item.description: An innovative approach to discovering, analyzing, and governing identity usage beyond traditional IAM controls. The Challenge: Identity Lives Outside the Identity Stack Identity and access management tools were built to govern users and directories. Modern enterprises run on applications. Over time, identity logic has moved into application code, APIs, service accounts, and custom authentication
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Google Looker Bugs Allow Cross-Tenant RCE, Data Exfil
item.description: Attackers could even have used one vulnerable Lookout user to gain access to other GCP tenants' environments.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: SolarWinds Web Help Desk Vulnerability Actively Exploited
item.description: CISA has added a critical CVE in SolarWinds Web Help Desk to its KEV Catalog

item.title: The First 90 Seconds: How Early Decisions Shape Incident Response Investigations
item.description: Many incident response failures do not come from a lack of tools, intelligence, or technical skills. They come from what happens immediately after detection, when pressure is high, and information is incomplete. I have seen IR teams recover from sophisticated intrusions with limited telemetry. I have also seen teams lose control of investigations they should have been able to handle. The
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: OfferUp scammers are out in force: Here’s what you should know
item.description: The mobile marketplace app has a growing number of users, but not all of them are genuine. Watch out for these common scams.

item.title: Microsoft Warns Python Infostealers Target macOS via Fake Ads and Installers
item.description: Microsoft has warned that information-stealing attacks are "rapidly expanding" beyond Windows to target Apple macOS environments by leveraging cross-platform languages like Python and abusing trusted platforms for distribution at scale. The tech giant's Defender Security Research Team said it observed macOS-targeted infostealer campaigns using social engineering techniques such as ClickFix since
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Eclipse Foundation Mandates Pre-Publish Security Checks for Open VSX Extensions
item.description: The Eclipse Foundation, which maintains the Open VSX Registry, has announced plans to enforce security checks before Microsoft Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extensions are published to the open-source repository to combat supply chain threats. The move marks a shift from a reactive to a proactive approach to ensure that malicious extensions don't end up getting published on the Open VSX Registry.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISA Adds Actively Exploited SolarWinds Web Help Desk RCE to KEV Catalog
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Tuesday added a critical security flaw impacting SolarWinds Web Help Desk (WHD) to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, flagging it as actively exploited in attacks. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-40551 (CVSS score: 9.8), is a untrusted data deserialization vulnerability that could pave the way for remote
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Chrome Add-On Caught Stealing Amazon Commissions
item.description: <p>A Chrome extension posing as an Amazon ad blocker was caught hijacking affiliate links in the background, redirecting commissions without user consent.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-amazon-ads-blocker-extension-affiliate-hijacking/">Chrome Add-On Caught Stealing Amazon Commissions</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: Russian Hackers Weaponize Microsoft Office Bug in Just 3 Days
item.description: APT28's attacks rely on specially crafted Microsoft Rich Text Format (RTF) documents to kick off a multistage infection chain to deliver malicious payloads.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: GlassWorm Malware Returns to Shatter Developer Ecosystems
item.description: The self-replicating malware has poisoned a fresh set of Open VSX software components, leaving potential downstream victims with infostealer infections.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: AI May Supplant Pen Testers, But Oversight &amp; Trust Are Not There Yet
item.description: Crowdsourced bug bounties and pen-testing firms see AI agents stealing the low-hanging vulnerabilities from their human counterparts. Oversight remains key.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: New Microsoft Update Improves Windows Sign-In Experience
item.description: <p>Windows 11’s optional KB5074105 update fixes the missing password icon bug linked to August 29, 2025’s KB5064081 and delivers 32 improvements.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-windows-11-stability-patch/">New Microsoft Update Improves Windows Sign-In Experience</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Joseph Ofonagoro

item.title: Docker Fixes Critical Ask Gordon AI Flaw Allowing Code Execution via Image Metadata
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a now-patched security flaw impacting Ask Gordon, an artificial intelligence (AI) assistant built into Docker Desktop and the Docker Command-Line Interface (CLI), that could be exploited to execute code and exfiltrate sensitive data. The critical vulnerability has been codenamed DockerDash by cybersecurity company Noma Labs. It was addressed by
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 8-Minute Access: AI Accelerates Breach of AWS Environment
item.description: The AI-assisted attack, which started with exposed credentials from public S3 buckets, rapidly achieved administrative privilges.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Dark Patterns Undermine Security, One Click at a Time
item.description: People trust organizations to do the right thing, but some websites and apps have user interfaces that ultimately lead to inadequate security.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: Hundreds of Malicious Crypto Trading Add-Ons Found in Moltbot/OpenClaw
item.description: A security researcher found 386 malicious ‘skills’ published on ClawHub, a skill repository for the popular OpenClaw AI assistant project

item.title: SQL Injection Flaw Affects 40,000 WordPress Sites
item.description: 40,000 WordPress sites are vulnerable to SQL injection in Quiz and Survey Master plugin

item.title: DockerDash Exposes AI Supply Chain Weakness In Docker's Ask Gordon
item.description: DockerDash vulnerability allows RCE and data exfiltration via unverified metadata in Ask Gordon

item.title: UK ICO Launches Investigation into X Over AI Generated Non-Consensual Sexual Imagery
item.description: UK Data Protection Watchdog has “serious concerns” over data privacy on Elon Musk’s social platform

item.title: [Webinar] The Smarter SOC Blueprint: Learn What to Build, Buy, and Automate
item.description: Most security teams today are buried under tools. Too many dashboards. Too much noise. Not enough real progress. Every vendor promises “complete coverage” or “AI-powered automation,” but inside most SOCs, teams are still overwhelmed, stretched thin, and unsure which tools are truly pulling their weight. The result? Bloated stacks, missed signals, and mounting pressure to do more with less. This
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Hackers Exploit Metro4Shell RCE Flaw in React Native CLI npm Package
item.description: Threat actors have been observed exploiting a critical security flaw impacting the Metro Development Server in the popular "@react-native-community/cli" npm package. Cybersecurity company VulnCheck said it first observed exploitation of CVE-2025-11953 (aka Metro4Shell) on December 21, 2025. With a CVSS score of 9.8, the vulnerability allows remote unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Warn of New “Vect” RaaS Variant
item.description: A new ransomware-as-a-service operation dubbed “Vect” features custom malware

item.title: Cybercrime Unit of Paris Prosecutors Raid Elon Musk’s X Offices in France
item.description: Elon Musk and X’s former CEO were summoned for voluntary interviews in Paris on April 20, 2026

item.title: Microsoft is Giving the FBI BitLocker Keys
item.description: <p>Microsoft <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/thomasbrewster/2026/01/22/microsoft-gave-fbi-keys-to-unlock-bitlocker-encrypted-data/">gives</a> the FBI the ability to decrypt BitLocker in response to court orders: about twenty times per year.</p> <blockquote><p>It&#8217;s possible for users to store those keys on a device they own, but Microsoft also recommends BitLocker users store their keys on its servers for convenience. While that means someone can access their data if they forget their password, or if repeated failed attempts to login lock the device, it also makes them vulnerable to law enforcement subpoenas and warrants.</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: When Cloud Outages Ripple Across the Internet
item.description: Recent major cloud service outages have been hard to miss. High-profile incidents affecting providers such as AWS, Azure, and Cloudflare have disrupted large parts of the internet, taking down websites and services that many other systems depend on. The resulting ripple effects have halted applications and workflows that many organizations rely on every day. For consumers, these outages are
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
